div.p: RAM-ALLEY: Or Merrie-Trickes. A COMEDY Diuers times here-to-fore acted By the Children of the Kings Reuels.
AT LONDON Printed by G. Eld, for Robert Wilson, and are to be sold at his shop in Holborne, at the new gate of Grayes Inne. 1611.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: HOme-bred mirth our Muse doth sing,
The Satyres tooth and Waspish sting,
Which most do hurt when least suspected,
By this Play are not affected;
But if Conceit with quick-turn'd Sceanes,
Obseruing all those ancient streames,
Which from the Horse-foot fount do flow,
As Time, Place, Person, and to show,
Things neuer done with that true life,
That thoughts and wits shall stand at strife,
Whether the things now shewne be true,
Or whether wee our selues now do
The things wee but present: if these
Free from the loathsome stage disease,
(So ouer-worne, so tirde and stale,
Not Satyring but to raile,)
May win your fauours, and inherit
But calme acceptance for his merit:
A vowes by Paper, Pen and Inke,
And by the learned Sisters drinke,
To spend his Time, his Lamps, his Oyle,
And neuer cease his braine to toyle,
Till from the silent houres of night,
Hee doth produce for your delight,
Conceits so new, so harmlesse free,
That Puritanes them-selues may see
A Play, yet not in publique Preach,
That Players such lewd doctrine teach
That their pure ioynts do quake and tremble,
When they doe see a man resemble
The Picture of a Villaine: This
As hee a friend to Muses is,
To you by mee a giues his word,
Is all his Play doth now affoord.

div.head: Ramme-Alley.
Actus 1. Scaena 1,
div.stage: Enter Constantia sola, with a letter in her hand.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: IN this disguise, (ere scarce my mourning robes)
Could haue a generall note, I haue forsooke,
My shape, my mother. and those ritch demeanes,
Of which I am sole heyre, and now resolue,
In this disguise of Page to follow him,
Whose loue first caused me to assume this shape.
Lord how my feminine bloud stirs at the sight
Of these same breeches, me thinkes this cod-peece
Should betray mee: well, I will trye the worst,
Hether they say hee vsually doth come,
Whom I so much affect, what makes he heere
In the skirts of Holborne, so neere the field,
And at a garden house, a has some punke
Vpon my life: no more heere hee comes.
God saue you sir: your name vnlesse I erre,
Is maister Thomas Boutcher.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: 'Tis sweet boy. Con. deliuers the lett.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I haue a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The inside sir will tell you: I shall see he reads it.
What loue he beares me now.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Th'art welcome boy.
How does the faire Constantia Somerfield,
My noble mistresse.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Shee giues thee heere good words, and for her sake,
Thou shalt not want a maister, be mine for euer.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I thanke you sir: now shall I see the Punke. he knocks

div.stage: Enter William Small-shanke.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.p: Who knocks so fast? I thought 'twas you, what news.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.p: You know my businesse well, I sing one song.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Foot, what would you haue me do, my land is gon,
My credit of lesse trust then Courtiers words
To men of iudgment, and for my debts
I might deserue a Knight-hood; what's to be done?
The Knight my father will not once vouchsafe
To call me sonne; That little land a gaue,
Throte the Lawyer swallowed at one gob,
For lesse then halfe the worth, and for the Citty
There be so many rascals, and tall yeomen
Would hang vpon me for their maintenance,
Should I but peepe or step within the gates,
That I am forst onely to ease my charge,
To liue here in the suburbes: or in the towne
To walke in Tenebris, I tell you sir,
Your best retierd life is an honest Punke
In a thatcht house with Garlike: tell not mee,
My Punk's my Punke, and noble Letchery
Sticks by a man, when all his friends forsake him.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: The Poxe it will, art thou so sencelesse growne,
So much indeared to thy bestiall lust,
That thy originall worth should lye extinct
And buried in thy shame? farre be such thoughts
From spirits free and noble: begin to liue,
Know thy selfe, and whence thou art deriu'd,
I know that competent state thy father gaue,
Cannot be yet consum'd.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: 'Tis gon by Heauen,
Not a denier is left.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Impossible zart, I haue had two suckers,
Able to spend the wealthy Craesus store.

div.stage: Enter Francis.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Why a Lawyer and a Whore,
See heere comes one, doost thinke this petti-coate,
A perfum'd smock, and twice a weeke a bathe,
Can be maintain'd with halfe a yeares reuenews,
No by Heauen, wee Annuall yonger brothers,
Must go to't by hole-sale, by hole-sale man
These creatures are maintaind: her very face
Has cost a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: They keepe this whore betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You know sir,
I did inioy a quiet country life,
Spotlesse and free, till you corrupted mee,
And brought me to the Court, I neuer knew,
What sleeking, glazing, or what pressing meant,
Till you preferd me to your Aunt the Lady,
I knew no Iuorie teeth, no caps of heire,
No Mercury water, fucas, or perfumes,
To helpe a Ladies breath, vntill your Aunt,
Learnt me the common trick.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: The common trick,
Say you, a poxe vpon such common tricks,
They will vndoe vs all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: And knowing this
Art thou so wilfull blind, still to persist
In ruine and defame.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: What should I doe?
I'aue past my word to keepe this Gentlewoman,
Till I can place her to her owne content,
And what is a Gentleman but his word.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Why let her goe to seruice.

sp.speaker: W S.
sp.l: To seruice,
Why so shee does, she is my Landeresse,
And by this light, no punie Inne a Court
But keepes a Landresse at his command
To doe him seruice, and shall not I, ha!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, you are his friend (I loue him to)
Propound a course which may aduantage him,
And you shall finde such reall worth in me,
That rather then Ile liue his hindrance,
I will assume the most penurious state
The Citty yeelds, to giue me meanes of life.

sp.speaker: W. S
sp.l: Why ther's it, you heare her what she sayes,
Would not he be damn'd that should forsake her,
Sayes she not well, can you propound a course,
To get my forfit land, from yonder roague,
Parcell Lawyer, parcell Deuill, all Knaue,
Thrate, throate.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Why so, I thought as much,
You are like our Cittizens to men in need,
Which cry 'tis pitty, a propper Gentleman,
Should want mony, yet not an vsuring slaue,
Will lend him a denier, to helpe his wants,
Will you lend mee forty shillings.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Why God-amercy, there's some goodnesse in thee,
Youle not repent.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: With that money
I will redeeme my forfit land, and wed
My Coccatrice to a man of worship,
To a man of worship by this light.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Thus in Ramme-alley lies a fellow, by name
Throte: one that professeth law, but indeed
Has neither law nor conscience, a fellow
That neuer saw the barre, but when his life
Was cald in question for a coosenage,
The Rogue is riche, to him go you, tell him
That rich Sir Iohn Somerfield.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Is lately dead, and that my hopes stand faire
To get his onely daughter. If I speed,
And haue but meanes to steale away the wench,
Tell him I reckon him my chiefest friend,
To entertaine vs till our nuptiall rites
May be accomplisht, and could you but procure
My elder brother meete me on the way,
And but associate me vnto his house,
'Tweare hit ifaith, I'de giue my cunning Throte
An honest slit for all his tricks in lawe.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Why this shall be perform'd, take ther's my store,
To friends all things are common.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Then at the court
There are none foes, for all things there are common.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will as carefully performe thy wish,
As if my fortunes lay vpon th'attempt.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: When shall I heere from you.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Let me alone for the rest, if I gull not
And go beyond my open throted lawyer,
For all his booke cases of Tricesimo nono
And Quadragessimo octauo: let mee
Like waiting Gentlewomen be euer bound,
To sit vpon my heeles, and pick rushes,
Will you about this geere.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: Then fare you well, yole meete me.

div.stage: Exit Bouch: and Page.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Adue: now you pernicious Coccatrice,
You see how I must skelder for your good,
Ile bring you where you shall haue meanes to cheate,
If you haue grace enough to apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Beleeue me loue, how ere some stricter wits,
Condemne all women which are prone to loue,
And thinke that if their fauour fall on any,
By consequence they must be naught with many,
And hold a false position, that a woman
False to her selfe, can trusty be to no man,
Yet know I say, how ere my life hath lost
The fame which my Virginity aspyr'd,
I will be true to thee, my deed shall mooue,
To win from all men pitty, if not loue.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Tut, I know thee a good rascall, lets in,
And on with all your neate and finest ragges.
On with your cloake and saue-gard, you arrant drab,
You must cheate without all conscience, filtch for thee & me.
Do but thou act what I shall well contriue,
Weele teach my Lawyer a new way to thriue. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mistresse Tafata, and Adriana her maid aboue.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come lou'd Adriana heere let vs sit,
And marke who passes; now for a wager,
What colourd bear'd comes next by the window?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I thinke not so,
I thinke a redde, for that is most in fashion,
Lord how scarce is the world of propper men
And gallants; sure wee neuer more shall see
A good legge worne in a long silke stocking,
With a long cod-peece, of all fashions
That carried it ifaith, what's he goes by?

div.stage: Enter a Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A sniueling Cittizen, he is carrying ware, Exit.
Vnto some Ladies chamber: but whoe's this?

div.stage: Enter T. Smal-shanke reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: I know him not, a lookes iust like a foole.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He's very braue a may be a Courtier,
Whats that a reads.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Ah how light a treads
For durting his silke stockings, Ile tell thee what,
A witty woman may with ease distinguish,
All men by their noses, as thus: your nose
Tuscan is louely, large and brawde,
Much like a Goose, your valiant generous nose.
A croked smoth and a great puffing nose,
Your schollers nose is very fresh and raw
For want of fire in winter, and quickly smells,
His choppes of mutton, in his dish of porrage.
Your Puritan nose is very sharpe and long,
And much like your widdows, and with ease can smell,
An edefying capon some fiue streets off,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: O mistris a very proper gentleman,

sp.speaker: Tafa.
sp.l: And trust me so it is, I neuer saw
A man that sooner could captiue my thoughts
(Since I writ widdow) then this gentleman,
I would a would looke vp.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Ile laugh so loud
That he may here me.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: And spake you with Maister Smalshanke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A said a woud,
And I beleeued him, I tell you maister
I haue done that for many of these gallants
That no man in this towne would do but I.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why trust them on their words
But will you heare the newes which now supplies,
The citty with discourse.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This sir, they say some of our citty dames
Were much desirous to see the Baboones
Doe their newest trickes, went, saw them, came home,
Went to bed, slept, next morning one of them,
Being to shift a smocke, sends downe her maide,
To warme her one, meane while she gins to thinke
On the Babones tricks, and naked in her bed
Begins to practise some, at last she stroue,
To gett her right leg ouer her head; thus:
And by her actiuity she got it
Crosse he shoulder: but not with all her power,
Could she reduce it, at last much strugling
Tumbles quite from the bed vpon the flower,
The maide by this return'd with the warme smocke,
And seeing her mistris throwne on the ground
Trust vp like a foote-ball, exclaimes, calles helpe,
Runnes downe amazd, sweares that her mistris necke
Is broke vp comes her husband and neighbours,
And finding her thus trus'd, some flatly said
She was bewitch, others she was possest,
A third said for her pride, the Diuell had set
Her face where her rumpe should stand, but at last
Her valiant husband steppes me boldly to her,
Helpes her; she a a shamed; her husband amazed,
The neighbours laughing as none forbeare,
She tells them of the fatall accident.
To which one answers, that if her husband
Would leaue his trade, and carry his wife about
To doe this tricke in publike, she'd get more gold
Then all the Babones, Calues with two tayles,
Or motions what soeuer.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: He wilbe gone if we neglect to stay him.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Noe I ha't stand a side,
Aye me my handkertcher Adriand, Fabia.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Runne, runne I haue let my handkertcher fall,
Gentleman shall I intreate a curtesie,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Within my power your beauty shall command.
What curtesie ist.

sp.speaker: Tas.
sp.l: To stoope and take vp,
My handkertcher.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir most hearty thankes: please you come in
Your welcome shall transcend your expectation.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I accept your curtesie, ha! whats this?
Assayld by feare and hope in a moment.
Boucher this womanish passion fits not men,
Who know the worth of freedome: shall smyles and eyes
With their lasciuious glances conquer him
Hath still beene Lord of his affections?
Shall simpring nisenesse load-stones but to fooles,
Attract a knowing spirrit: it shall, it dooes,
Not Phaebus rising from Auroras lap,
Spreds his bright raies with more maiestique grace
Then came the glances from her quickning eye
And what of this.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: By my troth I know not

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will not enter: continued flames burne strong,
I yet am free and reason keepes her seate,
Aboue all fond affections yet is she fayre.

div.stage: Enter Adriana.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Sir I bring you thankes for this great curtesie,
And if you please to enter I dare presume,
My mistris will afford you gratious welcome,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: How doe men call your mistris.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Her name sir is Mistris Changeable, late wife
To maister Tafata Mercer deceast.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: I haue heard she is both rich and beautifull,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: In th' eyes of such as loue her, iudge your selfe.
Please you but pricke forward and enter,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Now will I fall a boord the wating maide,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Fall a boord of me, dost take me for a ship,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I And will shoote you betwixt wind and water.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Blurt maister gunner your linstocks to short.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Foote how did she know that, dost here sweet hart
Should not the page be doing with the maid,
Whilst the maister is busie with the mistris,
Please you pricke forwards, thou art a wench
Likely to goe the way of all flesh shortly

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: At mine faith, I should breetch thee.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I breetch thee, I haue breetch a taler man,
Then you in my time, come in and welcome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well I see now a ritch well-practis'd baud,
May pursse more fees in a summers progresse,
Then a well traded lawier in a whole terme,
Pandarisme! why't is growne a liberall science
Or a new sect, and the good professors
Will like the Brownist frequent grauell pits shortly,
For they vse woods and obscure holes already.
Not marry a widdow.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And why?
Belike you thinke it base and seruant-like,
To feed vpon reuersion, you hold vs widdowes,
But as a pie thrust to the lower end
That hath had many fingers int before,
And is reseru'd for grose and hungry stomackes.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Come in faith you do:
And let me tell you thats but ceremony,
For though the Pye bee broken vp before,
Yet sayes the prouerbe, the deeper is the sweeter.
And though a capons wings and legges be caru'd,
The flesh left with the rumpe I hope is sweet.
I tell you sir, I haue beene woed, and sued to,
By worthy Knights of faire demeanes: nay more,
They haue bin out of debt, yet till this houre,
I neither could indure, to be in loue.
Or be beloued, but proferd ware is cheape.
whats lawfull thats loathd, and things denied,
Are with more stronger appetite persude.
I am to yeelding.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You mistake my thoughts.
But know thou wonder of this continent,
By one more skyld in vnknowne fate, then was,
The blind Achaian Prophet, It was foretold,
A widdow should indanger both my life,
My soule, my lands, and reputation,
This cheks my thoughs, and cooles th'ssentiall fire,
Of sacred loue; more ardent in my brest
Then speech can vtter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: A triuiall Idle ieast,
Tis for a man, of your repute, and note,
To credit fortunetellers, a petty rogue,
That neuer saw fiue shillings, in a heape
Will take vpon him to diuine mens fate,
Yet neuer knowes himselfe, shall die a begger,
Or be hanged vp for pilfering tablecloaths,
Shirts and smocks, hanged out to dry on hedges,
Tis meerely base, to trust them, or if there be,
A man in whome the Delphicke, God hath breathed,
His true diuining fire, that can foretell,
The fixt decree of fate, he likewise knowes,
What is within the euerlasting booke,
Of Desteny decreed cannot by wit,
Or mans Inuention be disolued, or shund,
Then giue thy loue free scope imbrace and kisse,
And to the distafe sisters leaue th'euent,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How powerfull are their words whome we affect,
Small force shall need, to winne the strongest fort,
If to his state the Captaine be perfidious,
I must intreate you licence my depart
For some few houres.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Choose what you will of time,
There lyes your way.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Who gins to loue, needs not a second Hell.

div.stage: Ent. Adr.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I prythee see if hee haue left the house,
Peepe close, see, but be not seene: is a gon.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Nay, keep you close y'ad best.

sp.speaker: Bou,
sp.l: O you much partiall gods!
Why gaue you men affections, and not a power
To gouerne them? what I by fate should shunne,
I most affect, a widdow, a widdow.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A ha, h'is in ifaith,
Yo'aue drawne him now within your purlews mistresse.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Tut I will not loue, my rationall
And better parts shall conquer blind affections,
Let passion children, or weake women sway,
My loue shall to my iudgement still obay.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: A went his way, and neuer lookt behind him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A little sing'd or so,
Each thing must haue beginning, men must prepare
Before they can come on, and show their loues
In pleasing sort: the man will doe in time,
For loue good Mistresse is much like to waxe,
The more 'tis rub'd, it sticks the faster too,
Or like a bird in bird-lime, or a pit-fall,
The more a labours, still the deeper in.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come, thou must helpe me now, I haue a trick
To second this beginning, and in the nick,
To strike it dead ifaith, women must woe,
When men forget what Nature leads them too.

div.stage: Enter Throte the Lawyer from his study bookes and bags of money on a Table, a chaire and cushion.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Chast Phoebe, splende; there's that left yet,
Next to my booke, Claro micante Auro,
I that's the soule of lawe: that's it, that's it,
For which the Buckrome bag must trudge all weathers:
Though scarcely fild with one poore replication,
How happy are we that wee ioy the law,
So freely as we doe; not bought and sold,
But clearely giuen, without all base extorting,
Taking but bare ten Angels for a fee,
Or vpward: to this renown'd estate,
Haue I by indirect and cunning meanes,
In-wouen my selfe, and now can scratch it out,
Thrust at a barre, and cry my Lord as low'd,
As ere a listed gowne-man of them all.
I neuer plead before the honor'd bench,
But bench right-worshipfull of peacefull Iustices
And Country-Gentlemen, and yet I'aue found
Good gettings by the Masse, besides od cheates,
Will Small-shankes lands and many garboyles more,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Haue you drawn't at length, haue you dasht it out,
According to your name.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is the demurror drawne twixt Snip and Woodcock,
And what doe you say to Peacocks pittifull bill,

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: I haue drawne his answer negatiue to all.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Negatiue to all. The plaintiue sayes,
That William Goose, was sonne to Thomas Goose,
And will a sweare the generall bill is false.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then he forsweares his father, 'tis well,
Some of our clients will go prig to hell
Before ourselues; has a paide all his fees.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: A lest them all with me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then trusse my points,
And how thinkst thou of law?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Most reuerently,
Law is the worlds great light, a second sunne,
To this terrestriall Globe, by which all things
Haue life and being, and with-out which
Confusion and disorder soone would seaze
The generall state of men, warres, outrages,
The vlcerous deeds of peace, it curbes and cures,
It is the kingdomes eye, by which shee sees
The acts and thoughts of men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The kingdomes eye,
I tell thee foole, it is the kingdomes nose,
By which she smells out all these rich transgressors,
Nor ist of flesh but meerely made of wax,
And tis, within the power of vs Lawiers,
To wrest this nose of waxe which way we please.
Or it may be as thou saist an eye indeed.
But if it be tis sure a womans eye knocke within.
Thats euer rowling.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go see who tis,
Stay, my chaire, and gowne, and then go see who knocks.
Thus must I seeme a Lawyer which am indeed,
But meerly dregs and offscumme of the Law, En. Bou. Dash. and Consta.
I tricesimo primo Alberti Magni
Tis very cleere.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The place is very pregnant, Maister Boucher;
Most harty welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You ply this geere,
You are no trewant in the law, I see.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some hundred bookes in folio I haue
Turnd ouer to better my owne knowledge,
But that is nothing for a studient,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Or a Stationer they turne them ouer too,
But not as you doe gentill Maister Throat,
And what? the Law speakes profit does it not?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some bad angells haunt vs now and then,
But what brought you hether.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I am in Law.
But let that goe, and tell me how you doe,
How does Will Smalshankes and his louely bride,

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Introth you make me blush, I should haue ask't,
His health of you, but tis not yet to late.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Nay good sir Throat forbeare your quillets now,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By Heauen I deale most plaine, I saw him not,
Since last I tooke his Morgage.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Sir be not nyce,
(Yet I must needs herein commend your loue)
To let me see him; for know I know him wed,
And that a stole away Sommerfields heire,
Therefore suspect me not I am his friend,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: How wed to ritch Sommerfields onely heyre,
Is old Sommerfield dead?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: By heauen I know it nor.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Then am I greeued.
I spake so much (but that I know you loue him.
And is reseru'd for grose and hungry stomackes.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Come in faith you do:
And let me tell you thats but ceremony,
For though the Pye bee broken vp before,
Yet sayes the prouerbe, the deeper is the sweeter.
I should intreat your secresie sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: Nay good sir stay, if ought you can disclose
Of Maister Smale-shankes good, let me pertake,
And make me glad in knowing his good hap.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You much indeere him sir, and from your loue,
I dare presume you make your selfe a fortune
If his fayre hopes proceede.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Or be my tongue torne out.

sp.speaker: Bouch.
sp.l: Measure for a Lawyer, but to the poynt
Has stole Somerfields heyre hether a brings her
As to a man on whom a may rely
His life and fortunes: you hath a named
Already for the Steward of his lands,
To keepe his Courts, and to collect his rent,
To let out Leases and to rayse his fines,
Nothing that may, or loue, or profit bring,
But you are named the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am his slaue
And bound vnto his noble curtesie-
Euen with my life, I euer said a would thriue,
And I protest I kept his forfeit morgage,
To let him know what tis to liue in want.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: I thinke no lesse, one word more in priuate.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Good Maister Dash shall I put you now a case.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then thus it is,
Suppose I am a Page, he is my Maister,
My Maister goes to bed and cannot tell
What monei's in his hose, I ere next day
Haue filcht out some, what action lies for this.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: An action boy, cald firking the Posteriors,
With vs your action sildome comes in question:
For that tis knowne that most of your Gallants
Are sildome so well stor'd, that they forget
What mone'i's in theyr hose, but if they haue,
There is noe other helpe then sweare the page
And put him to his oath.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Then fecks-law,
Dost thinke that he has conscience to steale,
Has not a conscience likewise to deny.
Then hange him vp ifayth.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Commend me to them, come when they will,
My dores stand open and all within is theirs
And though Ramme stinks with Cookes and ale,
Yet say thers many a worthy lawyers chamber,
Buts vpon Rame-alley, I haue still an open throte,
If ought I haue which may procure his good,
Bid him command, I, though it be my blod. Ex.

div.head: Actus Secundi. Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Oliuer Smaleshanke, Thomas Smale Shanke.

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.p: Is this the place you were appoynted to meete him.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: I find it true,
That wine, good newes, and a young holsome wentch
Chere vp an old mans bloud, I tel thee boy,
I am right harty glad, to heare thy brother;
Hath got so great an heire; now were my selfe,
So well bestowed I should reioyce ifaith.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.p: I hope you shall doe well.

sp.speaker: S.O.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt.
A sirra has a borne the wentch away,
My sonne ifaith, my very sonne ifaith,
When I was young and had an able backe,
And wore the brissell on my vpper lipe,
In good Decorum I had as good conuayance,
And could haue ferd, and ferkt y'away a wench,
As soone as eare a man a liue; tut boy,
I had my winks, my becks treads on the toe,
Wrings by the fingers, smyles and other quirkes,
Noe Courtier like me, your Courtiers all are fooles,
To that which I could doe, I could haue done it boy.
Euen to a hare, and that some Ladies knowe,

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Sir I am glad this match may reconcile,
Your loue vnto my brother.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: Tis more then soe.
Ile seeme offended still though I am glad,
sp.stage: Enter Willian Smals-shanke Francis, Beard booted.
sp.l: Has got rich Sommer-fields heyre.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Come wench of gold,
For thou shalt get me gold, besides od ends
Of siluer: weele purchase house and land,
By thy bare gettings, wentch, by thy bare gettings,
How saiest Lieftenant-Beard, does she not looke
Like a wentch newly stole from a window?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Exceeding well she carries it by Ioue;
And if she can forbeare her Rampant tricke,
And but hold close a while twill take by Mars.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How now you slaue? my rampant trickes you rogue,
Nay feare not me my onely feare is still,
Thy filthy face betrayes vs, for all men know,
Thy nose stands compas like a bow,
Which is three quarters drawne, thy head.
Which is with greasy haire ore-spred,
And being vncurld and blacke as cole,
Doth show some Scullion in a hole
Begot thee on a Gipsie, or
Thy mother was some Colliers whore
My rampant tricks you rogue, thou't be descride
Before our plot be ended.

sp.speaker: W, S.
sp.l: What should descry him,
Vnlesse it be his nose? and as for that;
Thou maist protest a was thy fathers butler,
And for thy loue is likewise runne away,
Nay sweet Lieftenant now forbeare to puffe,
And let the brissells of thy beard growe downe-ward,
Reuerence my Punke and Pandarize a little,
Thers many of thy ranke that doe professe it,
Yet hold it noe disparagment.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall doe,
What fits an honest man.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why thats enough,
Foote my Father and the goose my brother,
Backe you two.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Retyer sweet Lieftenant,
And come not on, till I shall waue you on.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: It shalbe so, Ile cheate him thats flat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You are well met, know yee me good sir,
Belike you thinke I haue no eyes, no eares,
No nose to smell, and winde out all your tricks,
Y'haue stole Sir Somerfields heire, nay we can finde,
Your wildest paths, your turnings and returnes,
Your traces, squats, the insets, formes and holes,
You yongmen vse, if once cursagest wits
Be set a hunting, are you now crept forth,
Haue you hid your head within a suburbe hole
All this while, and are you now crept forth?

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: who told you so did lye,
Foote, a Gentleman cannot leaue the Citty
And keepe the suburbs to take a little Phisick,
But straite some slaue will say he hides his head:
I hide my head within a Suburbe hole,
I could haue holes at Court to hide my head,
Were I but so disposd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Thou varlet knaue,
T'hast stolne away Sir Iohn Somerfields heire,
But neuer looke for countenance from me,
Carry her whether thou wilt.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Father, father,
Zart will you vndoe your posterity.
Will you sir vndoe your posterity?
I can but kill my brother then hang my selfe,
And where is then your house, make me not dispare,
Foote now I haue got a wench, worth by the yeare
Two thousand pound and vpwards, to crosse my hopes:
Would ere a clowne in Christendom doo't but you.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Good Father, let him leaue this thundring,
And giue him grace.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Why law, my brother knowes
Reason, and what an honest man should doe.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Ile giue her some-what, though I loue not thee.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: My father right, I knew you could not hold
Out long with a woman, but giue some-thing
Worthy your gift and her acceptance father,
This chaine were excellent by this good-light,
Shee shall giue you as good if once her lands
Come to my fingring.

sp.speaker: S.O.
sp.p: Peace knaue, whats she your wife?

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: A Ruffian sir,
By heauen, as tall a man as ere drew sword,
Not being counted of the damned crew,
A was her fathers Butler, his name is Beard,
Of with your Maske, now shall you finde me true,
And that I am a sonne vnto a Knight,
This is my father.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I am indeed faire maide,
My stile is Knight: come let me kisse your lips.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: That kisse shall cost your chaine.

sp.speaker: S.O.
sp.l: It smacks ifaith,
I must commend your choise.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir I haue giuen
A longer venture then true modesty
Will well allow, or your more grauer witte
Commend.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: I dare be sworne she has.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not so,
The foolish knaue ha's beene accounted wilde,
And so haue I, but I am now come home,
And so will he.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: I by this light will I.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay sigh not.
For you shall finde him louing and me thankfull.
And were it not a scandall to my honour,
To be consenting to my sonnes attempt,
You should vnto my house, meane while take this,
As pledge and token of my after loue:
How long since dyed your father.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Some six weeks since.
We cannot stay to talke, for slaues pursue,
I haue a house shall lodge vs till the Priest
May make vs sure.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Well sirra, loue this woman,
And when you are man and wife bring her to me,
Shee shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I must be gone, I must a wooing too.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: Ioue and Priapus speed you, youle returne.

div.stage: Exit Sir Oliuer and Thom: Small-shanke.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Why this came cleanly off.
Giue me the chaine, you little Cockatrice,
Why this was luck, foote foure hundred crownes
Got at a clap, hold still your owne you whore,
And we shall thriue.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: I, when will your nose and beard performe as much.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am glad he is gon, a put me to the blush
When a did aske me of ritch Somerfields death.

sp.speaker: W S.
sp.l: And tooke not I my q: wast not good,
Did I not bring you off, you arrant drab,
Without a counterbuffe? looke who comes heere,
And three merry men, and three merry men,
And three merry men bee wee a.

div.stage: Enter Boutcher and Constantia.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Still in this vaine, I haue done you seruice,
The Lawyers house will giue you entertainment,
Bountifull and free.

sp.speaker: W. S
sp.l: O nay second selfe,
Come let me busse thy beard, we are all made,
Why are so melancholly, doost want money?
Looke heer's gold, and as wee passe along,
Ile tell thee how I got it, not a word
But that shee's Somerfields heyre, my brother
Swallowes it with more ease, then a Dutchman
Does flap-Dragons: a comes, now to my Lawyers:
Kisse my wife, good brother; shee is a wench
Was borne to make vs all.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: I hope no lesse,
Yo'are welcome sister into these our parts,
As I may say.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Come now to Ram-alley. There shalt thou lye,
Till I prouide a Priest.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: O villany!
I thinke a will gull his whole generation,
I must make one, since 'tis so well begun,
Ile not forsake him, till his hopes be wonne. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Throate, and two Cittizens.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are, so please your worship.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I am glad, keepe your mony, for law
Is like a Butlers box: while you two striue,
That picks vp all your mony, you are friends,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are so please you, both perfit friends.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Why so,
Now to the next Tap-house, there drinke downe this,
And by the opperation of the third pot.
Quarrell againe, and come to mee for law:
Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: The Gods conserne your wisdom. E. Ci.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why so, these are tricks of the long fifteenes,
To giue counsell, and to take fees on both sides,
To make 'em friends, and then to laugh at them.
Why this thriues well, this is a common trick:
When men haue spent a deale of mony in law,
Then Lawyers make them friends: I haue a trick
To go beyond all these, if Small-shanke come
And bring rich Somerfields heyre, I say no more,
But 'tis within this skonse to goe beyond them.

div.stage: Enter Dash.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: Here are Gentlemen in hast would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: I cannot know them sir
They are so wrapt in Cloakes.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: Yes sir, but shee's Maskt, and in her riding sute.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Goe, make hast, bring them vp with reuerence,
Oh are they ifaith, has brought the wealthy heire:
These stooles and cushions stand not handsomly.

div.stage: Enter William Smalshanke, Boutcher. Thomas Smalshanke, Francis, and Beard.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: Welcome loue, kisse this Gentlewoman, Throte.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Can you blame hir since she has rid so hard?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: A fire in the great chamber, quickly.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: I that's well said, we are almost weary,
But Maister Throte, if any come to inquire
For me, my brother, or this Gentlewoman,
Wee are not here, nor haue you heard of vs.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Not a word sir, heere you are as safe
As in your fathers house,

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Th'art not merry loue, good maister Throte
Bid this Gentlewoman welcome: she is one
Of whom you may receiue some courtesie
In time.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: She is most harty welcome,
Wilt please you walke into another roome,
Where is both bed and fire,

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: I, I, that that
Good brother lead her in, Maister Throte and I
Will follow instantly, now Maister Throte Exit.
It rests within your power to pleasure me,
Know that this same is sir Iohn Somerfields Heire,
Now if she chance to question what I am,
Say sonne vnto a Lord, I pray thee tell her
I haue a world of land, and stand in hope
To bee created Barron, for I protest
I was constrain'd to sweare it forty times
And yet shee'le scarce beleeue mee.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: pauca sapienti,
Let mee alone to set you out in length
And breadth:

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: I prethee doo't effectually:
Shat haue a quarter share by this good light,
In all she has, I prethee forget not
To tell her the Smal-shankes haue beene dancers,
Tilters, and very antient Courtiers,
And in request at Court since sir Iohn Short-hose
With his long silke stockings was beheaded,
Wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Excellent, Ile but shift my bootes, and then
Goe seeke a Priest, this night I will bee shure,
If we bee shure, it cannot be vndone,
Can it Maister Throte?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O sir not possible:
You haue many Presidents and booke Cases for't,
Bee you but shure and then let mee alone.
Viuat Rex, currat Lex and Ile defend you.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.p: Nay then hang care, come lets in.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: A ha,
Haue you stole her, fallere fallentem non est fraus. Exit. W. S,
It shall goe hard but I will strippe you boy.
You stole the wench, but I must her inioy. Exit
Come Adriana, tell me what thou think'st,
I am tickled with conceit of marriage,
And whom think'st thou (for mee) the fittest husband
What saist thou to yong Bouchor.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: A pretty fellow
But that his back is weake,

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: What dost thou say
To Throte the Lawier?

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: I like that well,
Were the Rogue a Lawyer, but he is none,
He neuer was of any Inne-of-court;
But Inne of Chancery, where a was knowne,
But onely for a swaggering whyfler,
To keepe out rogues, and prentises, I saw him,
When a was stockt for stealing the cookes fees.
A Lawyer I could like, for tis a thing,
Vsed by you Cittizens wiues, your husbands dead;
To get French-hoods you straight must Lawyers wed,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What saist thou then to Nimble Sir Oliu. Smal-shanck

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Faith he must hit the haire: a fellow fit,
To make a pritty Cuckold: take an old man,
Tis now the newest fashion, better be
An old mans darling, then a young mans warling,
Take me the old briske Knight, the foole is rich,
And wilbe strong enough to father children,
Though, not to get them.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Tis true he is the man,
Yet will I beare some dozen more in hand,
And make them all my gulls.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Mistris stand aside.
Young Boutcher comes let me alone to touch him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: The widdow sir is not to be spooke to,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Not speake to, I must speake with her.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Must you!
Come you with authority, or doe you come
To sue her with a warrant that you must speake with her.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O you would intreat it,
May not I serue your turne, may not I vnfold,
Your secrets to my Mistris, loue is your sute,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: And why did you fall off
When you perceiued my mistris was so cunning,
D'you thinke she is still the same.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why so,
I tooke you for a nouice; and I must thinke,
You know not yet the inwards of a woman,
Doe you not know that women are like fish,
Which must be strooke when they are prone to byte,
Or all your labours lost, but sir walke here.
And Ile informe my Mistris your desires.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And you would haue the widdow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: by Ioue
I neuer saw one goe about his busines
More vntowardly: why sir, doe not you know
That he which would be inward with the Mistris,
Must make a way first through the waiting mayde?
If youle know the widdowes affections
Feele first the waiting Gentle-woman; do it Maister,
Some halfe a dozen kisses were not lost
Vppon this Gentle-woman, for you must know
These wayting-maids are to their Mistresses
Like Porches vnto doores, you passe the one
Before you can haue entrance at the other:
Or like your musterd to your peece of brawne,
If youle haue one tast well you must not scorne
To bee dipping in the other, I tell you Maister
Tis not a few mens tales which they preferre
Vnto their Mistress, in compasse of a yeare-
Be ruld by me, vntrusse your selfe to her,
Out with all your loue-sicke thoughts to her,
Kisse her and giue her an angell to buy pinnes,
And this shall sooner winne her Mistris loue,
Then all your protestations, sithes and teares.
Here they come; to her bouldly Maister
Doe, but dally not, thats the widdowes phrase,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Most worthy fayre such is the power of loue
That now I come t'accept your proffered grace,
And with submissiue thoughts t'entreat a pardon
For my so grose neglect.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Theres no offence,
My mind is changed.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I told you as much before.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: With a hey passe with a repasse.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Deerest of women,
The constant vertue of your nobler mind
Speakes in your lookes: Nor can you entertaine
Both loue and hate at once.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Stand thou propitious, indeere me to thy loue

div.stage: Boutcher giues Adriana his purse secretly.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Deere Mistresse turne to this Gentleman, I protest,
I haue some feeling of his constant loue,
Cast him not away, trye his loue.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Why sir,
With what audatious front can you intreat
To inioy my loue, which yet not two houres since,
You scornfully refusd.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: My fate compeld me, but now farewell fond feare,
My soule, my life, my lands, and reputation,
Ile hazard all, and prize them all beneath thee.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: Which I shall put to tryall, lend me thy eare.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A pretty knaue, ifaith come home to night,
Shalt haue a posset and candi'd Eringoes,
A bed if need be to, I loue a life,
To play with such Babounes as thou.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Indeed,
But doost thinke the widdow wi'l haue my maister.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Ile tell thee then, wo't come.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Make him subscribe it, and then I vow,
By sacred Vestaes euer hallowed fier,
To take thee to my bed.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: Hee's worthy loue, whose vertues most excell.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Remember, what ist a match betwixt you Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I haue set the foole in hope, ha's vnder-tooke
To rid me of that fleshy Captaine Face,
Which sweares in Tauernes, and all Ordinaries,
I am his lawfull wife: hee shall allay,
The fury of the Captaine, and I secure,
Will laugh at the disgrace they both indure. Ex:

div.stage: Enter Throte and Francis.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Open your case, and I shall soone resolue you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: But will you do it truly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This Gentleman whom I so much affect,
I scarsly yet doe know, so blind is loue,
In things which most concernes it, as y'are honest
Tell me his birth, his state, and farthest hopes.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: He is my friend, and I will speake him truly,
He is by birth, sonne to a foolish Knight,
His present state I thinke will be the prison,
And farthest hope to be baild out againe,
By sale of all your land.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O mee accurst,
Has a no credit, Lands and Mannors.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: That lands he has lyes in a faire Church-yard,
And for his manners, they are so rude and vilde,
That scarce an honest man will keepe him company.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I am abus'd, coosned, and deceiu'd.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why that's his occupation, hee will cheate
In a cloake lin'd with Veluet, a will prate
Faster then fiue Barbers and a Taylor,
Lye faster then ten Citty occupiers,
Or cunning tradesmen: goes a trust
In euery Tauerne where has spent a fagot,
Sweares loue to euery whore, squires bawdes,
And takes vp houses for them as their husband.
A is a man I loue, and haue done much
To bring him to preferment.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is there no trust,
No honesty in men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some there is,
And 'tis all in the hands of vs Lawyers
And women, and those women which haue it,
Keepe their honesty so close, that not one
Amongst a hundred is perceiued to haue it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good sir, may I not by law forsake him
And wed another, though my word be past
To be his wife.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O questionlesse you may,
You haue many Presidents and booke-cases for't,
Nay, though you were married by a booke-case,
Of Milesimo sexantesimo, &c.
You may forsake your husband, and wed another,
Prouided that some fault be in the husband,
As none of them are cleare.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am resolu'd,
I will not wed him, though I beg my bread.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: All that I haue is yours, and were I worthy
To be your husband.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thanke you sir,
I will rather wed a most perfidious Redshanke,
A noted Iewe, or some Mechanick slaue,
Then let him ioy my sheets.

div.stage: Enter W Smal. Boutcher, T. Smal. Beard.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Now my Virago, 'tis done, all's cock-sure,
I haue a Priest will mumble vp a marriage,
Without bell, booke, or candle, nimble slaue,
A honest Welsh-man that was a Taylor,
But now is made a Curate.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: What all amort? whats the matter? do you here?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: What's the reason of this melancholly?

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Hold him to it wench,
And it 'twill hit by heauen: why art so sad?
Foote wench we will be married to night,
Weele sup at th'Myter, and from thence
My brother and we three will to the Sauoy,
Which done, I tell thee girle, weele hand ore head,
Goe to't pell mell for a maiden-head,
Come yo'are lusty, you wenches are like bells,
You giue no musick, till you feele the clapper,
Come Throte a tortch, we must be gon.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This fellow has no land; and which is worse,
Hee has no credit.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.l: How are we outstript,
Blowne vp by wit of man: Let vs be gone
Home againe, home againe, our market now is done.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: That were too great a scandall.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Most true,
Better to wed another then to returne
With scandall and defame; wed me a man
Whose wealth may reconcile your mothers loue,
And make the action lawfull.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But where's the man?
I like your councell, could you show the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: My selfe am he, might I but dare aspyre
Vnto so high a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Mistrisse, take the man,
Shall we be baffled with faire promises,
Or shall we trudge, like beggers back againe,
No, take this wise and vertuous man,
Who should a lose his legges, his armes, his eares,
His nose, and all his other members,
Yer if his tongue be left 'twill get his liuing,
Take me this man.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, this night he meanes to wed mee.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: If not by law, we will with power preuent it,
So you but giue consent.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ile muster vp my friends, and thus I cast it,
Whilst they are busie, you and I will hence
Directly to a Chappell, where a Priest
Shall knit the nuptiall knot ere they persue vs.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: O rare inuention, Ile act my part,
A owes mee thirteene pound, I say no more,
But there be catch-poles: speakest a match.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Get your sword
And me my buckler, nay you shall know
We are Tam marti quam mercurio,
Bring my cloake, you shall thether, Ile for friends,
Worship and wealth the Lawyers state attends.
Dash, we must beare some braine, to Saint Iohns streete,
Goe runne, flye: and a farre off enquire,
If that the Lady Somerfield be there,
If there, know what newes, and meete me straite
At the Myter doore in Fleet-streete, away,
"To get rich wiues, men must not vse delay.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Smalshanke, Iustice Tutchim.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.p: A hunting Sir Oliuer and drye-foote to,

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: We old men haue our cretchets, our conundrums,
Our fegares, quirks and quibibles,
As well as youth, Iustice Tutchim I goe
To hunt no Buck, but prick a lusty Doe,
I go in truth a wooing.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Then ride with me,
Ile bring you to my sister Somerfield.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Iustice not so: by her there hangs a Tale.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I likewise haue a sonne,
A villanous Boy, his father vp and downe,
What should I say, these Veluet bearded boyes,
Will still be doing, say what we old men can,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: And what of this Sir Oliuer, be plaine,

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.l: A nimble spirited knaue, the villaine boy,
Has one tricke of his sier, has got the wench.
Stolne your ritch Sisters heire.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Has done the deed, has peirst the vessells head,
And knowes by this the vintage.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: As I am by my councell well informed,
This very day,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Tut It cannot be,
Some ten miles hence I saw the maid last night.

sp.speaker: S. Ol,
sp.l: Maides may be maides to night and not to morrow.
Women are free and sell their maiden-heads,
As men sell cloth, by yard and handfull,
But if you chaunce to see your Sister widdow,
Comfort her teares and say her daughters matcht,
With one that has a knocker to his Father,
An honest Noble Knight.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Stand close Knight, close,
And marke this Captaines humor, his name is Puffe,
A dreames as a walkes, and thinkes no woman
Sees him but is in loue with him.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Twere braue,
If some great Lady, through a window spide me,
And straight should loue me, say she should send,
5000 pound vnto my Lodging,
And craue my company: with that mony,
I would make three seuerall cloakes, and line them
With blacke, Crimson, and Tawny three pyl'd veluet,
I would eate at Chares Ordinary, and dice
At Antonies: then would I keepe my whore,
In beaten veluet and, haue two slaues to tend her.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: What my case of Iustices,
What are you eaues-dropping or doe you thinke,
Your tawny coates with gresie facings here,
Shall carry it? Sir Oliuer Smal-shankes,
Know my name is Puffe, Knight, thee haue I sought,
To fright thee from thy wits.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Puffe,
We haue to many mad men already,

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How? I tell thee Iustice Tuchim, not all
Thy Baylifes, Sergants busie Constables,
Defesants, warrants, or thy Mittimusses,
Shall saue his throte from cutting if he presume,
To woe the widdow eclipped Tafata,
Shee is my wife by oth. Therefore take heed,
Let me not catch thee in the widdowes house,
If I doe, Ile picke thy head vpon my sword,
And pisse in thy very visnomy, beware, beware.
Come there no more, a Captains word,
Flies not so feirce as doth his fatall sword, Exit Puffe.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: How like you this, shall we indure this thunder,
Or goe no further.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: We will on Sir Oliuer,
We will on, let me aloue to touchim,
I wounder how my spirit did forbeare,
To strike him on the face: had this beene spoke,
Within my Liberties, had dyed for it.

div.stage: Enter Cap. Puffe.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: If you come there,
Thy beard shall serue to stuffe, those balls by which
I get me heat at Tenice.

sp.speaker: I Tu.
sp.l: Is he gon. Exit Puffe.
I would a durst a stood to this awhile,
Well I shall catch him in a narrow rome,
Where neither of vs can flinch; If I do,
Ile make him daunce a trenchmoor to my sword,
Come Ile along with you to the widdow.
We will not be out-braued, take my word,
Weele not be wronged while I can draw a sword. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Throte and other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Let the Cotch stay at Showlane end: be ready,
Let the boote stand open, and when she's in:
Hurry towards Saint Gyles in the field,
As if the Diuell himselfe were wagoner,
Now for an arme of oake, and heart of steele,
To bare away the wench, to get a wife,
A gentlewoman, a maid, nay which is more,
An honest maid, and which is most of all,
A rich and honest maid: O Ioue Ioue!
For a man to wed such a wife as this,
Is to dwell in the very suburbs of Heauen,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir she is rich
And a great heire.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dangerous? Lord where be those gallant spirits,
The time has beene when scarce an honest woman,
Much lesse a wench could passe an Inn of court,
But some of the fry would haue bene doing
With her: I knew the day when Shreds a Taylor
Comming once late by an Inne of Chancerie,
Was layd along, and muffled in his cloake,
His wife tooke in, Stytcht vp, turnd out againe,
And he perswaded all was but in iest,
Tut those braue boyes are gone, these which are left,
Are wary lads, liue poring on their bookes,
And giue their lynnen to their landresses,
By tayle, they now can saue their pursses,
I knew when euery gallant had his man.
But now a twelpenny weekely Landresse,
Will serue the turne to halfe a dosen of them,
Here comes my man, what newes.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: As you would wish.
The Lady Somer-field is come to towne,
Her horses yet are walking, and her men say,
Her onely daughter, is conuayd away,
Noe man knowes how: now to it mast,
You and your Seruant Dash are made for euer
If you but sticke to it now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Now show your selues at full, and not a man,
But shares a fortune with me if I speed.

div.stage: Enter William Smal-shanke Boutcher. Thomas Smal-shanke, Francis and Bear. with a torch.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Tut feare not vs be shure you runne away,
And weele performe the quarrell.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Beare vp the torch, and keepe your way apace
Directly to the Sauoy.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Haue you a Lycence,
Looke to that brother before you marry,
For feare the Parson loose his benifice.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Tut our Curat craues no lycence, a sweres
His liuing cam to him by a miracle,

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why a paid nothing fort,
A swares that few be free from Symony,
But onely welchmen, and those a sayes to,
Are but mountayne Priests.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: But hang him foole he lies,
Whats his reason?

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: His reason is this,
That all their liuings are so rude and bare,
That not a man, will venter his damnation
By giuing mony for them: a does protest,
There is but two paire, of hoose, and shooes,
In all his Parish.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Shall I be taught how to aduance my torch,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How an asse; die men like dogs.

sp.speaker: Th. S.
sp.l: Hold brother hold, Lieftenant.
Put vp as you are men, your wife is gonne.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: How, which way? this is some plot,

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: So has the wentch let vs persue a loofe,
And see the euent, this will proue good mirth,
When things vnshapde shall haue a perfit birth. Exit.

div.stage: Enter W. Smal-shancke Boucher, Thom. Smal. and Beard, their swords drawne.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Tis a thing vnpossible, they should be gon
Thus far and we not see them.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Vpon my life.
They went in by the Grey-hound, and so strooke,
Into Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Water at Docke,
A fico for her Docke, youle not be ruld.
Youle stil be obstinate, Ile pawne my fate,
She tooke a long shew-lane, and so went home,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I home; how could shee chose but go,
Seeing so many naked tooles at once,
Drawne in the streete?

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Come we will find her, or weele fire the Suburbs,
Put vp your tooles, letts first along show-lane,
Then straite vp Holborne, If we find her not;
Weele thence direct to Throtes, if she be lost
I am vndone and all your hopes are crost. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Smaleshankes, Iustice Tutchim, Mistris Tafata, Adriana.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: Sir Oliuer,
Will you shame your selfe, ha? You must be short,
Why what a word was that to tell a widdow?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: I ment I must be breefe.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tut.
sp.l: Why say so then,
Yet thats almost as ill; go to, speake on.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Widdow I must be breefe, what old men doe,
They must doe quickly.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Then good sir do it,
Widdowes are sildome slow to put men to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: And old men know their q's, my Loue you knowe,
Has beene protested long, and now I come
To make my latest tender, an old growne oake
Can keepe you from the raine, and stands as fayre
And portly as the best.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Yet search him well,
And wee shall find no pithe or hearty Timber
To vnderlay a building.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: I would that Oake
Had beene a fire: Forward good sir Oliuer,
Your Oake is naught: sticke not too much to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: If you can like, you shall be Ladified,
Liue at the court, and soone bee got with child,
What do you thinke we old men can do nothing?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You shall haue Iewels,
A Baboone, Parrat, and an Izeland Dog,
And I my selfe to beare you company.
Your Ioynter is fiue hundred pound by yeere,
Besides your Plate, your Chaines and houshould stuffe,
When enuious fate shall change this mortall life.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: But shall I not be ouer-cloyde with loue?
Will you nor be too busie shall I keepe
My chamber by the moneth, if I bee pleas'd
To take Physick, to send for Visitants,
To haue my maide read Amadis de Gaule,
Or Donzel del Phoebo to me? shall I haue
A Carotch of the last edition,
The Coatch-mans seate a good way from the Coatch,
That if some other Ladies and my selfe
Chance to talke bawdy, he may not ouer-heare vs.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Shall we haue two chambers?
And will you not presume vnto my bed,
Till I shall call you by my waiting maide.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And when I send her,
Will you not intice her to your lust,
Nor tumble her before you come to me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay let him do his worst, make your match sure,
And feare not me, I neuer yet did feare
Any thing my maister could doe to mee. Knock.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What noyse is that, goe see Adriana,
And bring me word: I am so haunted
With a swaggering Captaine, that sweares God blesse vs
Like a very Tarmagant, a Raskall knaue, Enter Adr.
That saies he will kill all men which seekes to wed me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O Mistrisse! Captaine Puffe halfe drunke, is now
Comming vp staires.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O God haue you no roome
Beyond this Chamber, has sworne to kill me,
And pisse in my very visnomy,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: What are you afraid Sir Oliuer?

sp.speaker: S. Ol
sp.l: Not affraid,
But of all men I loue not to meddle with a Drunkard:
Haue you any Rome backwards.

sp.speaker: Iu. Tu.
sp.l: Is there nere a Trunke or Cubbert for him,
Is there nere a hole backwards to hide him in.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Creepe vnder my Mistrisse Farthingale Knight,
That's the best and safest place in the Chamber.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: I there, there, that he will neuer mistrust.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Enter Knight, keepe close, gather your selfe
Round like a Hedge-hog stirre not what ere you neere,
See or smell Knight, God blesse vs, here a comes. Ent. C. Puff.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir get you gon.
Leaue my house, or I will haue you coniur'd
With such a spell, you neuer yet haue heard of,
Haue you no other place to vent your froth,
But in my house, is this the fittest place,
Your Captaineship can find to puff in: ha!

sp.speaker: Ca Pu.
sp.l: How, am I not thy spouse, didst thou not say,
These armes should clip thy naked body fast,
Betwixt two linnen sheetes, and be sole Lord
Of all thy pewter worke, thy word is past,
And know that man is powder, dust, and earth,
That shall once dare to thinke thee for his wife.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: How now you slaue, one call the Constable.

sp.speaker: C. Puf.
sp.l: No Constable with all his Holberteeres,
Dare once aduance his head, or peepe vp staires,
If I crye but keepe downe: haue I not liu'd,
And marched on the sieged walles,
In thunder, lightning, raine, and snow,
And eake in shotte of powdered balls,
Whose costly markes are yet to show?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Captaine Face, for my last husbands sake,
With whom you were familiarly acquainted,
I am content to winke at these rude tricks,
But hence, trouble me no more, if you doe,
I shall lay you fast, where you shall see
No Sunne or Moone.

sp.speaker: C, Puf.
sp.l: Nor yet the Northen Pole,
A fico for the Sunne and Moone, let me liue in a hole,
So these two starres may shine.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir, get you gon,
You swaggering, cheating, Turne-bul-streete roague,
Or I will hale you to the common-Iayle,
Where Lyce shall eate you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Go to, I shall spurne
And slash your petti-coate.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Runne to the Counter,
Fetch me a red-bearded Sargeant, Ile make
You Captaine thinke the Deuill of hell is come
To fetch you, if hee once fasten on you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Dambe thee & thy Sergeants, thou Mercers Punke.
Thus will I kick thee and thy Farthingales.

sp.speaker: C Pu.
sp.l: What do you cast your whelps.
What haue I found you sir? haue not I plast
My Sakers, Culuerings, Demi-culuerings,
My Cannons, Demi-cannons, Basilisks,
Vpon her breatch, and do I not stand,
Ready with my Pike to make my entry,
And are you come to man her?

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Are not her Bulwarkes Parrapets, Trenches,
Scarfes, Counter-scarfes, Fortifications,
Curtaines, Shaddowes, Mines, Counter-mines,
Rampires, Forts, Ditches, Workes, Water-workes,
And is not her halfe-moone mine, and do you bring
A rescue good-man Knight

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Call vp my men, Enter 2. or 3. with clubs.
Where be these knaues, haue they no ears or hearts,
Beate hence this rascall, some other fetch a warrant,
Ile teach him know himselfe.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis not your beard shall cary it, down with the rogue.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: A sirra, Ex: Face
I knew my hands no longer could forbeare him,
Why did you not strike the Knaue, sir Oliuer?

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: But then it was too late.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: What would you haue me do when I was downe,
And hee stood thundring with his weapon drawne,
Ready to cut my throte.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The roague is gon,
And heer's one from the Lady Somerfield,
To intreat you come with all the speed you can,
To Saint Iohns streete.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Gentlemen
I am sorry you should be thus disturbed
Within my house, but now all feare is past,
You are most welcome: supper ended,
Ile giue a gratious answer to your sute,
Meane while let nought dismay, or keepe you mute. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Throte, Francis, and Dash.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Pay the Coatch-man Dash, pay him well,
And thanke him for his speed. Now Viuat Rex,
The knot is knit, which not the law it selfe,
With all his Hydra heads and strongest nerues,
Is able to disioyne: Now let him hang,
Fret out his guts, and sweare the starres from Heauen,
A neuer shall enioy you, you shall be rich.
Your Lady mother this day came to towne
In your pursute: wee will but shift some ragges,
And straite goe take her blessing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That must not be,
Furnish me with Iewels, and then my selfe,
Attended by you man and honest Beard,
Will thether first, and with my Lady mother
Craue a peace for you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I like that well,
Her anger some-what calm'd, I brisk and fine,
Some halfe houre after will present my selfe
As sonne in law vnto her, which she must needs
Accept with gratious lookes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I when shee knowes
Before by me, from what an eminent plague
Your wisdome has preseru'd me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I, that, that,
That will strike it dead: but heere comes Beard.

div.stage: Enter Beard.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.p: What are you sure, tide fast by heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I now do call her wife, she now is mine,
Seald and deliuered by an honest Priest,
At Saint Giles in the field.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: O hard at hand,
And almost mad with losse of his faire bride,
Let not my louely Mistresse bee seene,
And see if you can draw him to compound
For all his title to her, I haue Sargiants
Ready to do the feate, when time shall serue.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Stand you aside deere loue nay I will firke
My silly nouice, as he was neuer firkt
Since Midwiues bound his noddle: heere they come.

div.stage: Enter W. Smallsh. Th. Smalsh. and Boucher.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: O Maister Throte, vnlesse you speake good newes,
My hopes are crost, and I vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I neuer thought you'd come to other end,
Your courses haue beene alwayes so prophane,
Extrauagant and base.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Nay good sir heare?
Did not my loue returne? came she not hether,
For Ioues loue speake.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir will you get you gon,
And seeke your loue elsewhere; for know my house
Is not to entertaine such customers
As you and your comrades.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Is the man mad,
Or drunke, why Maister Throte know you to whom
You talke so sawcily?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why vnto you,
And to your brother Smale-shaneks, will you be gon?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Nay good sir hold vs not in this suspence,
Answere directly, came not the Virgin hether.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Will you be gon directly, are you mad?
Come you to seeke a Virgin in Ram-alley
Soe neere an Inne of Court, and amongst Cookes,
Ale-men and Landresses, why are you fooles?

sp.speaker: W Sm.
sp.l: Sir leaue this firck of law, or by this light
Ile giue your throte a slit, came she not hether?
Answere to that poynt.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What, haue you lost her?
Come doe not gull your frinds.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: By heauen she's gon
Vnlesse she be return'd since wee last left you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Nay then I cry you mercy, she came not hether
As'am an honest man: Ist possible
A maid so louely, fayre, so well demeand,
Should be tooke from you? what from you three?
So yong, so braue and valliant Gentlemen?
Sure it cannot bee.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.p: To our pepetuall shames tis now too true.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is she not left behind you in the Tauerne?
Are you shure you brought her out? were you not drunke
And so forgot her?

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: A pox on all such luck,
I will find her, or by this good light
Ile fire all the Citty, come let's goe,
Who euer has her shall not long enioy her,
Ile proue a contract, lets walke the round,
Ile haue her if shee keepe aboue the ground. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, a makes me sport. ifaith
The gull is mad, starke mad, Dash draw the bond
And a release of all his interest
In this my loued wife,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I be sure of that,
For I haue certaine gobblins in buffe Ierkins Enter with the Sargeants.
Lye in ambuscado for him.

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Ile giue you baile
Hang off honest catch-poles

sp.speaker: M. Thr.
sp.l: good, wise,
Learned, and honest maister Throte, now, now,
Now or neuer helpe me..

sp.speaker: W. Sm.
sp.l: Here are two retainers, hangers on sir,
Which will consume more then ten liueries,
If by your meanes they be not straite shooke off:
I am arrested.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: But thirteene pound, due to Beard the Butler,
Do but baile me, and I will saue you harmelesse.

sp.speaker: Thr,
sp.l: Why heer's the end of Ryot, I know the law,
If you be baild by me, the debt is mine,
Which I will vndertake.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Law there; Roagues,
Foote I know hee would not let me want
For thirteene pounds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Prouided, you seale a release,
Of all your claime to Mistresse Somerfield.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Sergeants doe your kinde, hale me to the hole,
Seale a release, Sargeants come, to prison,
Seale a release for Mistrisse Somerfield,
First I will stinck in Iayle, be eate with Lyce,
Indure an obiect worse then the Deuill himselfe,
And that's ten Sergeants peeping through the grates
Vpon my lowsie linnen, come to Iayle,
Foote a release.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, impudent man.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: My wife, foote my wife, let me go Sergiants.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O thou perfidious man darst thou presume
To call her wife, whom thou so much hast wrong'd,
What conquest hast thou got, to wrong a maide,
A silly harmelesse maide? what glory ist
That thou hast thus deceiued a simple Virgin,
And brought her from her friends? what honor wast
For thee to make the Butler loose his office
And runne away with thee. Your tricks are knowne,
Didst thou not sweare thou shouldst be Baroniz'd?
And hadst both lands and fortunes? both which thou wantst.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Foote that's not my falt, I would haue lands
If I could get em.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I know your trick:,
And know I now am wife vnto this man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I thanke her sir, she has now voutchsaft
To cast her selfe on me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Therefore subscribe,
Take some-what of him for a full release,
And pray to God to make you an honest man,
If not, I doe protest by earth and Heauen,
Although I starue, thou neuer shalt inioy me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Her vow is past, nor will she breake her word;
Looke to it mitcher.

sp.speaker: W. S
sp.l: Foote shall I giue two thousand pound a yeare
For nothing.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Brother come, be rul'd by me,
Better to take a little then loose all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: You see shee's resolute, y'had best compound.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Ile first be damn'd ere I will lose my right,
Vnlesse a giue me vp my forfit morgage,
And baile me of this action.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir you may choose,
What's the morgage worth?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Doe it, doe it,
Come you shall do it, we will be rid of him
At any rate.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dash, go fetch his morgage,
See that your friends be bound, you shall not claime
Title, right, possession in part or whole,
In time to come, in this my loued wife:
I will restore the morgage, pay this debt,
And set you free.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: We will,
Come draw the bonds, and we will soone subscribe them.

div.stage: Enter Dash.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: They're ready drawne; here's his release,
Sergiants let him goe.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Was euer man thus cheated of a wife:
Is this my morgage.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Well I will subscribe, God giue you ioy,
Although I haue but little cause to wish it,
My heart will scarce consent vnto my hand,
Tis done.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You giue this as your deeds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You are, Sargeants I discharge you,
There's your fees.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Not so, I must haue money.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Foutr, words are winde,
I say I must haue money.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Three pounds in hand, and all the rest to morrow.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ther's your summe, now officers begon,
Each take his way, I must to Saint Iohns streete,
And see my Lady-mother: shee's now in towne,
And we to her shall straite present our duties.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: O Ioue shall we loose the wench thus.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Euen thus
Throte farewell, since 'tis thy luck to haue her,
I still shall pray, you long may liue together:
Now each to his affaires.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Good night to all, Ex:
Deare wife step in, Beard and Dash come hether:
Heere take this money: goe borrow Iewels
Of the next Gold-smith: Beard take thou these bookes,
Goe both to the Broakers in Fetter lane,
Lay them in pawne for a Veluet Ierken
And a double Ruffe, tell him a shall haue
As much for loane to night, as I do giue
Vsually for a whole circuit, which done
You two shall man her to her mothers: goe, Ex.
My fate lookes big; me thinkes I see already,
Nineteene gold chaines, seauenteene great beards, and ten
Reuerent bald heads, proclaime my way before me,
My Coatch shall now go prancing through Cheapside,
And not be forst to hurry through the streetes,
For feare of Sargeants: nor shall I need to trye,
Whether my wel-graft tumbling foot-cloth nag,
Be able to out-runne a wel-breath'd Catchpole,
I now in pompe will ride, for 'tis most fit,
Hee should haue state that riseth by his wit. Ex.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Sir Oliuer, Iustice Tutchim, Taffata, Adriana.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good meate the belly fils, good wine the braine,
Women please men, men pleasure them againe,
Ka me, ka thee, one thing must rub another,
English loue Scots, Welshmen loue each other.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: You say very right sir Oliuer, very right,
I haue't in my noddle ifaith, That's all the fault
Old Iustices haue, when they are at feasts,
They wil bib hard, they wilbe fine: Sun-burnt
Sufficient, foxt, or Columberd now and than,
Now could I sit in my charyre at home and nod
A drunkard to the stocks, by vertue of,
The last statute rarely.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir you are merry,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Your supper sir was light.
But I hope you thinke you welcome.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I doe,
A light supper quoth you, pray God it be,
Pray god I carry it cleanly, I am shure it lies,
As heauy in my belly as moult lead,
Yet Ile goe see my Sister Sommerfield,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I euen so late,
Night is the mother of wit, as you may see,
By Poets or rather Cunstables
In their examinations at midnight,
Weele lie together without marrying,
Saue the Curats fees, and the parish a labour,
Tis a thriuing course.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: That may not be,
For excomunications then will flee.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Thats true, they fly indeed like wild-geese,
In flocks, one in the breech of another.
But the best is a small matter stayes them,
And so farwell.

sp.speaker: S.O.
sp.l: Farwell good Iustice Tutchim, Exit.
Alasse good gentleman his braines are erased,
But let that passe: speake widdow ist a match,
Shall we clap it vp.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay if't come to clapping,
Good night ifaith Mistris looke before you,
Theres nothing more dangerous to maide or widdow,
Then suddaine clapings vp; nothing has spoyld,
So many proper ladies as clappings vp:
Your shittill-cocke, striding from tables to ground,
Onely to try the strength of the backe,
Your riding a hunting, I though they fall,
With their heels vpward, and lay as if
They were taking the height, of some high starre
With a crosse staffe: noe nor your iumlings
In horsslitters, coatches or caroatches,
Haue spoyld so many women as clappings vp,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.p: Why then weele chop it vp.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Thats not alowed.
Vnlesse you were sonne to a welch Curate:
But faith sir Knight I haue a kind of itching,
To be a Lady, that I can tell you woes,
And can perswade with better rethorick,
Then oathes, wit, welth, valour, lands, or person,
I haue some debts at court, and marrying you,
I hope the Courtier will not sticke to pay me,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: Neuer feare thy payment. This I will say,
For Courtiers theyle be shure to pay each other,
How ere they deale with Cittizens.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Then heres my hand,
I am your wife condition we be ioynd,
Before to morrows sunne.

sp.speaker: Si. O.
sp.l: Nay euen to night,
So you be pleas'd with little warning widdow,
We old men can be ready, and thou shalt see,
Before the time that chanticlere,
Shall call and tell the day is neere,
When wentches lying on their backs,
Receiue with ioy their loue-stolne smacks,
When maids awak't from their first sleepe,
Deceiu'd with dreames begin to weepe,
And thinke if dreames, sutch pleasures know,
What sport the substance them would show,
When Ladies gin white Lymmes to spred,
Her loue but new stolne to her bed,
His cotten showes yet scarce put off,
And deares not laugh, speake, sneze, or cough,
When precise dames begin to thinke,
Why their grose souring husbands stincke,
What pleasure twere then to inioy,
A nimble vickar, or a boy.
Before this time thou shalt behold,
Me quaffing out our brydall bole.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Then belike before the morning Sunne
You wil be coupled.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Well I will looke you shall haue a cleane smocke,
Prouided that you pay the fee Sir Oliuer,
Since my Mistris sir will be a Lady,
Ile loose no fees due to the wayting maid.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Why is there a fee belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A Knight and neuer heard of smocke fees,
I would I had the monopoly of them,
So there were no impost set vpon them: Enter W. Sm.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Whom haue wee heere what my mad-headed sonne
What makes he here so late? say I am gone,
And I the whilest will step behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.p: God Blesse thee parcell of mans flesh,

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Why parcell of mans flesh art not a woman?
But widdow whers the old stinkerd my father,
They say widdow you dance altogether.
After his pipe.

sp.speaker: W.S.
sp.l: Thar't a foole,
Ile assure thee theres no musick in it.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Better widdow?
Bloud dost thinke I haue not learnt my pricke song,
What not the court pricksong? one vp and another downe,
Why I haue't to a hare by this light.
I hope thou louest him not.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: How marry him, foote art mad widdow,
Woot marry an old crased man,
With meager lookes, with visage wan,
With littell legs and cryncled thies,
With Chapfalne gummes and deepe sunke eyes,
Why a dog seazd on ten daies by death
Stinkes nor so loathsome as his breath,
Nor can a citty common iaques,
Which all mens Breeches vndertakes,
Yeeld fasting stomakes such a fauour.
As doth his breath, and vgly fauour.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Thats all one sir she meanes to be a Lady,

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Does she so, and thou must be her waiting woman.
Faith thou wilt make a fine dainty creature,
To sit at a chamber doore and looke fleas,
In thy Ladies dog while she is showing,
Some slippery britcht Courtier rare faces,
In a by window, foote widdow,
Marry me a young and compleate gallant,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: How a compleat gallant? what? a fellow,
With a hat tuck't vp behind, and what we vse,
About our hips to keepe our coates from dabling,
He weares about his neeke, a farthingale:
A standing coller to keepe his neate band cleane,
The whilst his shirt does stinke, and is more foule,
Then an in of chancery table cloth,
His breeches must be pleyted as if a had
Some thirty pockets, when one poore halpeny purse,
Will carry all his treasure, his knees all points,
As if his legs and hammes were tyde together,
A fellow that has noe inside, but prates
By roate, as players, and parrotts vse to doe,
And to define a compleat gallant right,
A mercer form'd him, a taylor made him,
And a player giues him spright,

sp.speaker: Wi. Sm.
sp.l: Why so, in my conscience to be a Countesse,
Thou wouldst marry a hedg-hog: I must confesse,
Tis state to haue a coxe-combe kisse your hands,
While yet the chamberly is scarse wypte off,
To haue an vpright vsher march before you,
Bare headed in a Tuftafata ierkin
Maide of your old cast gowne, shewes passing well,
But when you feele your husbands pulses, thats hell,
Then you fly out and bid straite smockes farwell,

sp.speaker: Taf,
sp.l: I hope sir what ere our husbands be,
We may be honest.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: May be; nay y'are,
Women and honesty are as neere alyde,
As parsons liues are to their doctrines,
One and the same: but widdow now be ruld,
I hope the heauens will giue thee better grace,
Then to accept the father and I yet liue,
To be bestowed, if you wed the stinckerd,
You shall find the tale of Tantalus
To be noe fable widdow.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: How I sweate,
I can hold noe longer, degenerate bastard,
I here disclayme thee, casheere thee, nay more,
I disinherit thee both of my loue.
